diff_hunk:
@@ -1,2 +1,33 @@
 # SFWRENG_4G06
 This will be the private repo for our SFWR ENG 4G06 capstone project. The group members for the project will be able to commit to the repo.
+
+# How to Set Up The Database
+## Remote Database
+TBD
+## Local Database
+### Installation
+1. Download [MySQL](https://www.mysql.com) for your respective machine. 
+2. Follow their setup instructions in order to install it on your machine. 
+### Getting Started
+1. Fire up the MySQL Server (there's usually a "Start MySQL Server" button somewhere). 
+2. Once the server is started, open up a command prompt and type `mysql -u root -p` which will then require your 
+password. You may have to set up credentials so that you can use this command on your machine.
+3. The `mysql` prompt should now show up. Now type `create database VApp;`. This command will create the database that 
+we will load the `database.sql` file into. I couldn't think of anything else to call it :).
+4. Now enter `exit`; We are now going to load the database from the `database.sql` file, so hopefully you remember the
+path to that file. 
+5. `mysql -u root -p VApp < full/path/to/database.sql`. Enter your password once more, and the console 
+should freeze for a bit as it executes the SQL. 
+6. Now log in again and check if it worked: `mysql -u root -p`. Use
body: @KevinHardy-Cooper Add that if you are using Git Bash on Windows, you may have to type `winpty mysql -u root -p`

 This will be the private repo for our SFWR ENG 4G06 capstone project. The group members for the project will be able to commit to the repo.
+
+# How to Set Up The Database

+## Local Database
+### Installation

+2. Follow their setup instructions in order to install it on your machine. 
+### Getting Started
+1. Fire up the MySQL Server (there's usually a "Start MySQL Server" button somewhere). 
+2. Once the server is started, open up a command prompt and type `mysql -u root -p` which will then require your

+3. The `mysql` prompt should now show up. Now type `create database VApp;`. This command will create the database that 
+we will load the `database.sql` file into. I couldn't think of anything else to call it :).
+4. Now enter `exit`; We are now going to load the database from the `database.sql` file, so hopefully you remember the

+should freeze for a bit as it executes the SQL. 
+6. Now log in again and check if it worked: `mysql -u root -p`. Use
body:
Also, on Windows, to import the SQL file:

1. Copy the database.sql file to `C:\Program Files\MySQL\MySQL Shell 8.0\bin\`
2. In Git Bash, type `winpty mysql -u root -p`
3. Enter your password
4. Type `use VApp;`
5. Type `source database.sql`

Then just wait for all the records to be processed.

diff_hunk:
@@ -1,2 +1,18 @@
 # SFWRENG_4G06
 This will be the private repo for our SFWR ENG 4G06 capstone project. The group members for the project will be able to commit to the repo.
+
+## How To Setup Locally
+1. Turn on MySQL server 
+2. `node App.js`
body:
Let's make this is as specific as possible, especially for the TAs. For example:

### Getting Started
1. Make sure you have NodeJS and MySQL installed.
2. Open your terminal and navigate to a directory of your choice.
3. Clone the repository by running `git clone {insert url here}`
4. Obtain a copy (or create your own) SensitiveInfo.js file.
5. Create the database (link to steps in database on README)
6. Start the local MySQL server (include command).
7. Run `npm install`
8. Run `node App.js` to actually run the application.
9. Visit localhost/specific_url_of_home_page 
10. All done!
Is this the secure way to run a query? If not, please add a comment: `//TODO(kevin): Make this more secure`
I think these should be `const` not `let` but I could be wrong. Thoughts?
What are these supposed to be? Is host just localhost? Is user/password for the local MySQL server or something else? Please include these details in the README.
I didn't add any security for this pull request since this is just the barebones framework for the backend flow
can provide security using these methods: https://github.com/mysqljs/mysql#escaping-query-values

good question, based on this (https://dev.to/sarah_chima/var-let-and-const--whats-the-difference-69e), all variables should be declared by `let` and all constants should be declared by `const`. I will make this change now and rebase

I think you need to add mysql to your package.json. I am getting the following error:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13467791/50995137-2e1cfd80-14ec-11e9-9217-64e642b2261c.png)
I will include these in the README, good catch
i'll add mysql to package.json
Is this on purpose
Can you just leave it in, and add the stub?

It's commented out on purpose. I figured there's no point of a cumulative score function if we only have one social media platform. I can add in the the stub if you want, but if we don't end up using more than one social media then we have literally no use for this function in the code base
OK that's fair.
Add info in the README to explain what these are / how to get them
Don't store any secrets in the codebase. If this secret is used on the server or client side by the App please remove.
log errors using logger aswell. Same goes for the other errors

Should you send an error to the user as well?
res.send(err);
Add comments to describe function.. Do the same for all other added functions
Also add a link to twitter APi about the callback url

diff_hunk:
@@ -76,4 +88,37 @@ For JavaScript development, we will follow the following naming conventions:
 
 For Database development, we will follow the following naming conventions:
 * Database and tables will be named in Upper_Snake_Case
-* Columns will be named in lower_snake_case
\ No newline at end of file
+* Columns will be named in lower_snake_case
+
+## Endpoints
+`GET /` - Home page
+
+`POST /signup` - Sign up the user
+
+`POST /signout` - Sign out the user
+
+`POST /signin` - Sign in the user
+
+`GET /oauth` - Start OAuth process 
+
+`GET /oauth/callback` - Receives access tokens from Twitter
+
+`GET /oauth/:socialMedia` - Requests Twitter login page
+
+`GET /settings/:socialMedia` - Gets user's Twitter settings
+
+`GET /cumulativeScore` - Gets user's cumulative score
+
+`POST /cumulativeScore` - Inserts user's cumulative score
+
+`GET /score/:userId` - Gets user's scores
+
+`GET /score/:userId/:socialMedia` - Gets user's scores by social media
+
+`POST /score/:socialMedia` - Inserts user's social media score
+
+`GET /implications/:settingId` - Gets implications by setting
+
+`GET /instructions/:implicationId` - Gets instructions by implication
+
